sub_title: A researcher and development practitioner with more than 10 years of work experience. I am dynamic and capable of working in a holistic manner with a diverse group of stakeholders.
summary: My names are Alice Mapenzi Kubo. l am a graduate of International Development Studies (M.Sc.) and my M.Sc. study at the University of Amsterdam (UvA) was awarded cumlaude. My academic work has been published (in English, Dutch, French, German, Italian, Portuguese and Polish) and is available at many online bookstores. My work as a development practitioner, for more than 10 years, focused on program management and l collaborated with a diverse group of stakeholders. l have experience forging partnerships with international, regional, national and local level organisations, including non-governmental organisations (NGOs), government agencies, telecom companies, and other stakeholders. I have broad knowledge and experience in children’s rights and rights-based programming, monitoring and evaluation, and participatory approaches. I have conducted desk-research and field research. And l have knowledge about education and quality of education which stems from conducting research into the subject area and also from serving in the expert group on School Fees Abolition Initiative (SFAI) that was led by UNESCO-IIEP and UNICEF. The expert group developed the Operational Guide on the process of school fees abolition and safeguarding quality of education (the Operational Guide is available online). My expertise on research techniques, data collection and data analysis comes from my academic background and also from being a Jury Member of the Africa Thesis Award (see African Studies Centre Leiden University (ASCL)). I also have knowledge about the tourism industry after pursuing a Bachelor degree and specializing in sustainable tourism and development. My knowledge of environmental management was gained from studies on environment at the University of Amsterdam and from the British Open University, as well as volunteering for a Kenyan-based organisation that focuses on conservation and environmental matters. l am open to all areas of work, be it at an NGO, research institute, public sector, the private/corporate sector or other organisations or agencies. I enjoy ‘learning-by-doing’ and l have the ‘can-do-mentality’. My ambition remains being an ‘agent of change’ and if that change is driven by a NGO, or a bank, or a foundation or a research institute, l will embrace it and contribute to its efforts in achieving its vision, mission and values, among others.

I worked as a Secretary to the Chairperson: organizing events and carrying-out administrative tasks such taking minutes of meetings, among others; and together with the Chairperson, wrote the MMS Newsletter. I was also a member of the Organizing Group for the Vasco da Gama Commemoration Week in April 9-15, 1998 - Malindi's largest event ever.

Malindi Museum Society (MMS), is a member-based, civil society organisation dealing with matters affecting residents of Malindi, a town located in the Kenya Coast. MMS is active in environmental matters (e.g., the protection of the sea and its resources, conservation of tropical forests, and garbage collection issues), health issues (e.g., creating awareness and implementation of measures to lower malaria infections), and heritage and cultural issues (e.g., preservation of cultural artifacts, preserving history through building a Museum for the town and maintenance of historical monuments). 

Currently, I am a full member of MMS.
